 Table containing for each interrupt group the number of interrupt request lines and a pointer to the table of interrupt line handlers.
const unsigned int ipr_val [AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_LEVELS]
 Values to store in the interrupt priority registers for the various interrupt priority levels.

Detailed Description

INTC driver for AVR32 UC3.

AVR32 Interrupt Controller driver module.

  • Compiler: IAR EWAVR32 and GNU GCC for AVR32
  • Supported devices: All AVR32 devices with an INTC module can be used.
  • AppNote:
Author:
Atmel Corporation: http://www.atmel.com
Support and FAQ: http://support.atmel.no/

Definition in file intc.c.

Define Documentation

#define DECL_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE ( GRP,
unused   )     static volatile __int_handler _int_line_handler_table_##GRP[Max(AVR32_INTC_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP##GRP, 1)];

Creates a table of interrupt line handlers per interrupt group in order to optimize RAM space.

Each line handler table contains a set of pointers to interrupt handlers.

Definition at line 64 of file intc.c.

#define INSERT_INT_LINE_HANDLER_TABLE ( GRP,
unused   )     {AVR32_INTC_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP##GRP, _int_line_handler_table_##GRP},

__int_handler _get_interrupt_handler ( unsigned int  int_level  ) 

Gets the interrupt handler of the current event at the int_level interrupt priority level (called from exception.S).

Parameters:
int_level Interrupt priority level to handle.
Returns:
Interrupt handler to execute.

Definition at line 113 of file intc.c.

References _int_handler_table.

00114 {
00115   // ICR3 is mapped first, ICR0 last.
00116   // Code in exception.S puts int_level in R12 which is used by AVR32-GCC to
00117   // pass a single argument to a function.
00118   unsigned int int_grp = AVR32_INTC.icr[AVR32_INTC_INT3 - int_level];
00119   unsigned int int_req = AVR32_INTC.irr[int_grp];
00120 
00121   // As an interrupt may disappear while it is being fetched by the CPU
00122   // (spurious interrupt caused by a delayed response from an MCU peripheral to
00123   // an interrupt flag clear or interrupt disable instruction), check if there
00124   // are remaining interrupt lines to process.
00125   // If a spurious interrupt occurs, the status register (SR) contains an
00126   // execution mode and interrupt level masks corresponding to a level 0
00127   // interrupt, whatever the interrupt priority level causing the spurious
00128   // event. This behavior has been chosen because a spurious interrupt has not
00129   // to be a priority one and because it may not cause any trouble to other
00130   // interrupts.
00131   // However, these spurious interrupts place the hardware in an unstable state
00132   // and could give problems in other/future versions of the CPU, so the
00133   // software has to be written so that they never occur. The only safe way of
00134   // achieving this is to always clear or disable peripheral interrupts with the
00135   // following sequence:
00136   // 1: Mask the interrupt in the CPU by setting GM (or IxM) in SR.
00137   // 2: Perform the bus access to the peripheral register that clears or
00138   //    disables the interrupt.
00139   // 3: Wait until the interrupt has actually been cleared or disabled by the
00140   //    peripheral. This is usually performed by reading from a register in the
00141   //    same peripheral (it DOES NOT have to be the same register that was
00142   //    accessed in step 2, but it MUST be in the same peripheral), what takes
00143   //    bus system latencies into account, but peripheral internal latencies
00144   //    (generally 0 cycle) also have to be considered.
00145   // 4: Unmask the interrupt in the CPU by clearing GM (or IxM) in SR.
00146   // Note that steps 1 and 4 are useless inside interrupt handlers as the
00147   // corresponding interrupt level is automatically masked by IxM (unless IxM is
00148   // explicitly cleared by the software).
00149   //
00150   // Get the right IRQ handler.
00151   //
00152   // If several interrupt lines are active in the group, the interrupt line with
00153   // the highest number is selected. This is to be coherent with the
00154   // prioritization of interrupt groups performed by the hardware interrupt
00155   // controller.
00156   //
00157   // If no handler has been registered for the pending interrupt,
00158   // _unhandled_interrupt will be selected thanks to the initialization of
00159   // _int_line_handler_table_x by INTC_init_interrupts.
00160   //
00161   // exception.S will provide the interrupt handler with a clean interrupt stack
00162   // frame, with nothing more pushed onto the stack. The interrupt handler must
00163   // manage the `rete' instruction, what can be done thanks to pure assembly,
00164   // inline assembly or the `__attribute__((__interrupt__))' C function
00165   // attribute.
00166   return (int_req) ? _int_handler_table[int_grp]._int_line_handler_table[32 - clz(int_req) - 1] : NULL;
00167 }

void INTC_init_interrupts ( void   ) 

Definition at line 175 of file intc.c.

References _int_handler_table, _unhandled_interrupt(), INTC_init_evba(), and ipr_val.

00176 {
00177   unsigned int int_grp, int_req;
00178 
00179   INTC_init_evba();
00180 
00181   // For all interrupt groups,
00182   for (int_grp = 0; int_grp < AVR32_INTC_NUM_INT_GRPS; int_grp++)
00183   {
00184     // For all interrupt request lines of each group,
00185     for (int_req = 0; int_req < _int_handler_table[int_grp].num_irqs; int_req++)
00186     {
00187       // Assign _unhandled_interrupt as default interrupt handler.
00188       _int_handler_table[int_grp]._int_line_handler_table[int_req] = &_unhandled_interrupt;
00189     }
00190 
00191     // Set the interrupt group priority register to its default value.
00192     // By default, all interrupt groups are linked to the interrupt priority
00193     // level 0 and to the interrupt vector _int0.
00194     AVR32_INTC.ipr[int_grp] = ipr_val[AVR32_INTC_INT0];
00195   }
00196 }

unsigned int  irq,
unsigned int  int_level

Definition at line 199 of file intc.c.

References _int_handler_table, AVR32_INTC_MAX_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP, and ipr_val.

00200 {
00201   // Determine the group of the IRQ.
00202   unsigned int int_grp = irq / AVR32_INTC_MAX_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP;
00203 
00204   // Store in _int_line_handler_table_x the pointer to the interrupt handler, so
00205   // that _get_interrupt_handler can retrieve it when the interrupt is vectored.
00206   _int_handler_table[int_grp]._int_line_handler_table[irq % AVR32_INTC_MAX_NUM_IRQS_PER_GRP] = handler;
00207 
00208   // Program the corresponding IPRX register to set the interrupt priority level
00209   // and the interrupt vector offset that will be fetched by the core interrupt
00210   // system.
00211   // NOTE: The _intx functions are intermediate assembly functions between the
00212   // core interrupt system and the user interrupt handler.
00213   AVR32_INTC.ipr[int_grp] = ipr_val[int_level & (AVR32_INTC_IPR_INTLEVEL_MASK >> AVR32_INTC_IPR_INTLEVEL_OFFSET)];
00214 }
